articles.headline: ‘I’m Not Scared of Anything’: Death and Defiance in a Besieged Ukrainian City
articles.snippet: The port city of Mykolaiv is being shelled by Russian forces every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb.
articles.abstract: The port city of Mykolaiv is being shelled by Russian forces every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Alla Ryabko stood in the courtyard of the city morgue, trembling with grief and rage. Her son, Capt. Roman Ryabko, had been killed in fighting on the first day of the war in Ukraine, but two weeks had passed and his body had not yet been prepared for burial.

articles.headline: Dollars or Rubles? Russian Debt Payments Are Due, and Uncertain.
articles.snippet: Citing sanctions, the Russian government warned it might pay foreign debt obligations in rubles. Credit rating agencies say a default is imminent.
articles.abstract: Citing sanctions, the Russian government warned it might pay foreign debt obligations in rubles. Credit rating agencies say a default is imminent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia is teetering on the edge of a possible sovereign debt default, and the first sign could come as soon as Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson, Alan Rappeport and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: European Leaders Brave Russian Bombardment in Visit to Kyiv
articles.snippet: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.
articles.abstract: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three European leaders staged a defiant show of support for Ukraine on Tuesday, traveling to its besieged capital, Kyiv, even as a relentless Russian artillery bombardment left apartment towers in the city ablaze, forcing terrified residents to flee into the street with only the clothes on their backs.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: Pfizer and BioNTech Seek Authorization of a Second Booster Shot for Older Americans
articles.snippet: The move could further inflame a tortuous debate among scientists over when the coronavirus vaccines’ protection should be bolstered, and for whom.
articles.abstract: The move could further inflame a tortuous debate among scientists over when the coronavirus vaccines’ protection should be bolstered, and for whom.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pfizer and BioNTech said on Tuesday that they had sought emergency authorization for a second booster shot of their coronavirus vaccine for adults 65 and older.

articles.headline: Refugee Crisis Will Test a European Economy Under Pressure
articles.snippet: Resettling the refugees fleeing Ukraine could cost $30 billion in the first year alone, and the permanent integration of millions of people would reshape Europe’s economy.
articles.abstract: Resettling the refugees fleeing Ukraine could cost $30 billion in the first year alone, and the permanent integration of millions of people would reshape Europe’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone who crossed the Danube on the open-air ferry from Ukraine and landed in the frostbitten Romanian port city of Isaccea on a recent morning had a roller bag and a stopgap plan. One woman planned to join her husband in Istanbul. Another was headed to Munich, where her company has its headquarters. Others were meeting brothers, cousins, in-laws and friends in Paris or Sofia, Madrid or Amsterdam.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Cristian Movila

articles.headline: A Hollywood Production (Made in Liverpool)
articles.snippet: Netflix, Amazon Prime and other studios are snapping up soundstages in Britain and building more, drawn by an experienced labor pool and alluring tax incentives.
articles.abstract: Netflix, Amazon Prime and other studios are snapping up soundstages in Britain and building more, drawn by an experienced labor pool and alluring tax incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — For two decades, the Littlewoods building in Liverpool, a long, low-slung and cavernous space built to house a betting and mail-order company in the 1930s, sat abandoned. No one wanted to take on this crumbling hulk looming on the outskirts of the city.

articles.headline: Oligarchs Got Richer Despite Sanctions. Will This Time Be Different?
articles.snippet: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.
articles.abstract: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time the United States government slapped his family with sanctions and locked him out of the American financial system, Arkady Rotenberg waited about eight weeks, investigators say, before buying a $7.5 million painting in New York City.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Jane Bradley

articles.headline: Beating Japan at Its Own (Video) Game: A Smash Hit From China
articles.snippet: Genshin Impact, a nearly picture-perfect reproduction of Japanese fantasy role-playing games, has raked in billions of dollars and sent shock waves through the world’s aging video game superpower.
articles.abstract: Genshin Impact, a nearly picture-perfect reproduction of Japanese fantasy role-playing games, has raked in billions of dollars and sent shock waves through the world’s aging video game superpower.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Genshin Impact, one of the world’s hottest mobile video games, has all the characteristics of a Japanese invention: giant robots; human-size swords; characters with huge eyes and spiky, rainbow-colored hair; and a puzzling fixation on women in maid outfits.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Why rates are going up.
articles.snippet: The central bank wants a strong economy, but sustainability is the name of the game: A little pain today could mean less pain tomorrow.
articles.abstract: The central bank wants a strong economy, but sustainability is the name of the game: A little pain today could mean less pain tomorrow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prices for groceries, couches and rent are all climbing rapidly, and Federal Reserve officials have been warily eyeing that trend.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Karl Russell

articles.headline: As Jackson Faces Senators, Her Criminal Defense Record Is a Target
articles.snippet: Republicans have vilified Biden’s judicial nominees who have represented criminal suspects. Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, for the Supreme Court, is the most prominent.
articles.abstract: Republicans have vilified Biden’s judicial nominees who have represented criminal suspects. Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, for the Supreme Court, is the most prominent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Josh Hawley had a pointed question earlier this month for a federal appeals court nominee who, as a public defender, helped get a Pennsylvania man off death row despite his conviction for two brutal murders.

articles.headline: Starbucks C.E.O. retires, and Howard Schultz steps in as interim chief executive.
articles.snippet: Kevin Johnson, who was named chief executive in 2017, will leave his post on April 4.
articles.abstract: Kevin Johnson, who was named chief executive in 2017, will leave his post on April 4.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two years, even as the pandemic shut down key markets and created supply shortages, Kevin Johnson, the chief executive of Starbucks, managed to lead the company to robust revenue and profit growth.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Noam Scheiber
